Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Increasing Accessibility and Discoverability at the Alaska Native Language Archive

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Endangered language archives play an important role in creating access to a region's cultural, historical and linguistic knowledge for the general public and scholars from a range of disciplines. Obtaining access to archived information can be a complex task. For a non-specialist user, it can be difficult to choose the right terms to type into a search box. The better the catalogue description attached to an archived item, the better the chances that a distant user may be able to access it. This project, focused on archived Native American language materials, will create a process for describing and integrating the combined knowledge that layers of annotation represent, so that users can better access those materials. The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. Knowledge of these languages deepens and enriches our understanding of our multicultural history; it is in the national interest to preserve and share this knowledge. Linguistic documentation of Native American languages has been preserved in libraries and archives since colonial times, but modern technology has given archivists new ways to share access to information. The Alaska Native Language Archive (ANLA) handles Native Language materials for all of the twenty-two Alaska Native Languages, as well as serving as a repository for related languages. This project seeks to broaden and improve access to materials held by ANLA by creating a workflow for the curation of important collections to create access for stakeholders in Alaska Native communities as well as in academic and pedagogical circles. Broader impacts also include the training of a graduate student, and the benefits from modernization of the workflow and the protocols for handling new deposits.

ANLA seeks to increase discoverability and reproducibility of data on the region's indigenous languages through professionalization of the archive. The archive has always depended on collection improvement by knowledgeable users. This used to take the form of annotation to folders of papers, or transcriptions of recordings: a linguist would contribute notes after studying the work of other linguists, and these notes would form a new archived item. In the digital world, the layers of relationships between a recording and its derivatives (like transcriptions or other notes and annotations on the content) require careful organization to maintain. With the rapid advances in information science, adding staff with this expertise and ideally also in linguistics will enhance the discoverability and usability of ANLA's data sets, which represent some of the richest language deposits existing for Alaskan and Arctic languages. This project will develop protocols, workflow, and collection management practices in line with best approaches in archival sciences. As a test case, this project will develop a workflow for collection improvement by focusing on a specific subcollection and developing it to its best access level. To do this, a graduate student will annotate and re-catalogue a large set of texts in a single language (Lower Tanana Dene/Athabascan) to demonstrate how subcollection development can improve access for academic and other stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goal

This project was undertaken in order to make it easier to find and understand materials housed in the Michael E. Krauss Alaska Native Language Archive. ANLA is part of the Alaska and Polar Regions Collections and Archives at the Elmer E. Rasmuson Library, University of Alaska Fairbanks. The project funded salary for a project manager for the archive, who created a manual of systems, policies and workflows that can be used by future staff to process, keep track of and share materials, both physical and digital. New activities arising from the project manager?s work were also funded by the grant, and resulted in the development of a new language documentation project.

Activities

Dr. Sarala Puthuval was hired in  2017 to serve as project manager. She began work in February of 2018. Dr. Puthuval created protocols, workflows and forms for ANLA, and also participated in outreach for the archive, including presentations at CoLang  2018 and at the International Conference on Documentation and Conservation in Honolulu in 2019, as well as two site visits to Alaskan villages.

Intellectual Merit

This project supported access to the only archive in Alaska that handles indigenous language materials for all the Alaska Native Languages. ANLA contains the original work of a remarkable group of descriptive linguists and the Alaska Native language speakers who have worked with them: Michael Krauss, Eliza Jones, Edna MacLean, Knut Bergsland, Irene Reed, James Kari, and Jeff Leer, to name only a few. The project improved protocols that safeguard original materials created by these language workers while also making it easier for language learners and researchers to find and use these materials.

Broader Impacts

Even as the number of native speakers of the languages dwindles, Alaska Native language revitalization activities are booming. For learners and teachers, the Alaska Native Language Archive has become ever more important as a source for language learning and teaching materials. ANLA's mission to stakeholder language communities is fundamental. While improved access to linguistic documentation is important for the academic disciplines of linguistics, anthropology and history (at least), improved access to ANLA's holdings for stakeholder communities is even more crucial to the continued understanding and use of the languages. It is especially important to develop systems to share legacy materials creatively with non-academic users in culturally appropriate ways, while maintaining broad access for all.

Summary

The Alaska Native Language archive and its stakeholder communities ? Language communities, educators and researchers ? benefit greatly from the improvements supported by this project. Depositors, users and archive staff now have a set of clear guidelines for ingestion, processing and discoverability of materials. Work with a  subcollection, documentation of the Sugs'tsun (Alutiiq) language, formed the basis for the involvement of an undergraduate student, Ivana Ash, a member of the language community. Work on this collection sparked new connections and a visit to Nanwalek, and this outreach effort brought about a new funded project to support language documentation and revitalization in this community.
